body_html:
@shamoya, I just noticed this odd behavior, too. It seems that somehow the code got a RDMA_MESSAGE_TENSOR_REQUEST but thought it got a RDMA_MESSAGE_ACK . Note that in the log PS also received a RDMA_MESSAGE_ACK from worker 1, but worker 1 only sent a RDMA_MESSAGE_TENSOR_REQUEST .

I am running it on x86_64. How can I check the endian issue? Is endian handled by the Infiniband driver?
body_text:
@shamoya, I just noticed this odd behavior, too. It seems that somehow the code got a RDMA_MESSAGE_TENSOR_REQUEST  but thought it got a RDMA_MESSAGE_ACK . Note that in the log PS also received a RDMA_MESSAGE_ACK  from worker 1, but worker 1 only sent a RDMA_MESSAGE_TENSOR_REQUEST .
I am running it on x86_64. How can I check the endian issue? Is endian handled by the Infiniband driver?
body:
@shamoya, I just noticed this odd behavior, too. It seems that somehow the code got a `RDMA_MESSAGE_TENSOR_REQUEST ` but thought it got a `RDMA_MESSAGE_ACK `. Note that in the log PS also received a `RDMA_MESSAGE_ACK ` from worker 1, but worker 1 only sent a `RDMA_MESSAGE_TENSOR_REQUEST `.

I am running it on x86_64. How can I check the endian issue? Is endian handled by the Infiniband driver?
